awd_titl_txt: Statistical Inference and Experimental Design for Recurrent Event Data with Applications in Neuroscience
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern technologies allow neuroscientists to record and control neural activities at cellular resolution in living, intact brains.  While these technologies open up a path toward understanding the brain, they also pose new challenges for neuroscientists and statisticians.  Modern neuroscience experiments produce massive recordings of neural activities in the form of recurring spikes.  Despite the large volume, missing data and measurement errors pose significant statistical challenges.  Moreover, with techniques such as optogenetics and multi-photon imaging, it is increasingly clear that statistical experimental designs should be utilized to facilitate modern neuroscience experiments.  The research focuses on answering two questions of interest to the scientific community: (1) how to rigorously analyze the newly-acquired neural data, and (2) how to optimally design neuroscience experiments to aid scientific discovery.

There are two main aims in this research project. The first aim focuses on the development of statistical theory and methods for analyzing neural data using a class of point process models known as the Hawkes process.  While the Hawkes process is widely used in neuroscience applications, the underlying theoretical properties are not well-studied.  The proposed research will seek to (a) develop novel theory for the Hawkes process under realistic assumptions, (b) establish a causal inference framework for partially observed networks using instrumental variables, and (c) account for calibration errors in spike detection.  In the second aim, an automatic procedure for model-based design of optogenetics experiments for mapping neural microcircuits will be developed leveraging results obtained as part of the first aim.  Computationally efficient algorithms for online learning and designing on neural data will also be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed projects are motivated by the escalating volume and complexity of recurrent event data from designed experiments. These experiments are pivotal in uncovering causal relationships within multivariate systems, particularly in the field of neuroscience. The primary goals of this proposal are to develop statistical theory and methods for analyzing modern neural data sets that emerge from novel neuroscience experiments, and to establish a rigorous framework for causal inference on neural data.

Under the support of this award, the PI has successfully developed novel statistical methods to address significant challenges in the analysis of neural data. This endeavor has led to two primary outcomes:

(i) The creation of exploratory data analysis tools designed for the examination of large-scale neural data across diverse subjects. These tools offer semiparametric estimation for typical neural activities, while accommodating individual variability. By generalizing techniques from clustering, stochastic block models, and shape invariant models to point process data, we have proposed efficient algorithms capable of analyzing the simultaneous activities of thousands of neurons.

(ii) The establishment of a causal inference framework for point process treatments, incorporating the use of instrumental variables. This novel framework effectively characterizes the latent confounding issues, enabling researchers to design experiments that adhere to the necessary identification assumptions of the causal estimands.

The impact of these projects extends beyond their initial scope, as the developed statistical methods are poised to make immediate and substantial impacts on the analysis and discovery processes in neural data. In particular, the proposed causal inference framework can be readily applied to the design of a wide range of neuroscience experiments; the exploratory data analysis tools will be available on the Internet to the general public with interactive scripts with examples to illustrate how to apply the code on real data.
